answers.author: Sam Anselm
answers.text:
We offer this service through our website provider, CivicPlus. Our local emergency management director oversees the list and notification process. In addition the Red Cross has an app, and we also encourage residents to have A NOAA weather radio. I would be happy to talk more about this if you have additional questions.

answers.author: Jesse Himes
answers.text:
Hi Joseph,
Great question. Many local governments are looking at doing things like texting their citizens updates about the community or during emergencies.
The 311/CRM topic page is full of resources dedicated to that sort of thing.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/1/311CRM_Systems
Another interesting program related to mobile technology and SMS is “EMS SignPost.”
http://icma.org/en/Article/104659/EMS_SignPost_Project
Painesville, Ohio has been rolling out their new “911Cellular” system that sends notifications to hose that are registered.
http://icma.org/en/Article/104760/City_of_Painesville_OH_Switches_to_NEW_Emergency_Notification_System__911Cellular
I hope this helped!
Jesse Himes, Knowledge Network Intern, jhimes@icma.org

author: Joseph Gacioch
text:
The City of Ferndale, Michigan is looking to enlist a subscription SMS service that enables residents to register for push notifications related to general seasonal updates and possibly emergency notifications.  We hope the solution is built upon a database that will provide the city with useful and usable data of our userbase.  
Can anyone provide an example of a positive experience with SMS subscriptions messaging and how they manage this service internally?
title: SMS Subscription Services
